Headline: Graciela Iturbide's iconic black & white images
Article_Body: "Angelita," Sonoran Desert, (1979). For Iturbide, the act of photographing is a mutual exchange between photographer and subject, infusing her work with uncommon energy and power. "Novia Muerte" (Death Bride). "I am a feminist," said Iturbide. "And as I am, in my photographs, my way of being is revealed. That does not mean that I deliberately do feminist photography. I do what surprises me."  "Mexico City" (1969-72). Iturbide is not just a witness to the lives of her subjects but an active participant, attending cultural festivals and going to the market with the women she photographs.  "El Baño de Frida, Coyoacán, Ciudad de México" (Frida's Bathroom, Coyoacán, Mexico City), (2005). Iturbide venerates esoteric and ephemeral symbols of Mexico's national identity like the belongings of Frida Khalo.  "Carmen, La Mixteca" (1992). Through Iturbide's lens we see marginalized communities portrayed with complexity and compassion. "In Magnolia con sombrero (Magnolia with Sombrero)," Juchitán (1986). Iturbide profiles a Muxe, a third-gendered person from Juchitán. "Saguaro," Sonoran Desert, (1979).  It's these wistful turns that Iturbide distills into gelatin prints of art. A cactus is not just a cactus but a symbol of humanity. "Autorretrato como Seri (Self-Portrait as Seri)," Sonoran Desert (1979). "Something is beautiful when it touches my heart. My eyes see them, and my heart shoots them," said Iturbide.
